Situation1: A dispatch call sends the ambulance driver through heavy city traffic to a location where a patient has a non-life-threatening injury.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: The city traffic was a tangled mess, horns blaring and cars inching forward. I gripped the steering wheel, glancing at the clock on the dashboard. The dispatch call had come just as I was about to leave for church, a routine I rarely missed. The patient wasn’t in critical danger, but protocol demanded I get there as quickly as possible. My pastor always said that commitment to the church community was a reflection of faith, and I knew people would notice my absence. Yet, as an ambulance driver, I was trusted to put safety first, never risking lives by rushing recklessly. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my duty to my patient, my responsibility to my faith. I could feel the tension in my chest, torn between the flashing lights above me and the church bells ringing in my mind.
